time.question: How long does it take to learn a new language?
time.answer: Results vary depending on your commitment and goals. Our users generally notice significant improvement after just 3 months of daily use (10-15 minutes per day).

levels.question: What levels are available on Linguify?
levels.answer: Our courses cover all levels, from beginner (A1) to advanced (C2) according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).

devices.question: Can I access Linguify on multiple devices?
devices.answer: Yes, your subscription allows you to access Linguify on all your devices. Your progress is automatically synchronized.

teachers.question: Are there real teachers behind Linguify?
teachers.answer: Absolutely. Our platform combines AI technology with the expertise of certified language teachers who create and supervise the educational content.

story.title: Our Story
story.paragraph1: Founded in 2023 by Louis-Philippe Lalou and Lionel Hubaut, Linguify emerged from a shared vision to transform global education. As part of Next-Corporation, we identified the growing need for innovative language learning solutions that could bridge cultural gaps and create opportunities for people worldwide.
story.paragraph2: Our focus extends beyond just language learning - we're building tools that promote international cohesion, enhance employment opportunities, and contribute to a more connected global society. Through our platform, we're making quality language education accessible to everyone, everywhere.

note1.title: Conjugation - Spanish irregular verbs
note1.content:
Lista de verbos irregulares más comunes:
• Ser/Estar (to be)
• Ir (to go)
• Tener (to have)
• Hacer (to do/make)

Notes: Irregular verbs often follow patterns that can be grouped...

note2.title: Vocabulary - Traveling in Italy
note2.content:
• Buongiorno = Good morning/hello
• Arrivederci = Goodbye
• Per favore = Please
• Grazie = Thank you
• Quanto costa? = How much does it cost?
• Dov'è...? = Where is...?

note3.title: German grammatical structure
note3.content:
Rule: In German, the conjugated verb always occupies the second position in a declarative sentence.

Examples:
- Ich gehe nach Hause. (I'm going home)
- Heute gehe ich nach Hause. (Today I'm going home)
